com.bigdata.rdf.store

Interface BDS


  • public interface BDS
    A vocabulary for the bigdata full text search facility. Full text search may be used to combine text search and graph search. Low-latency, user facing search applications may be created by slicing the full text search results and feeding them incrementally into SPARQL queries. This approach allows the application to manage the cost of the SPARQL query by bounding the input. If necessary, additional results can be feed into the query.
    Version:
    $Id: BD.java 6786 2012-12-19 18:43:27Z thompsonbry $
    Author:
    Bryan Thompson
    See Also:
    SliceServiceFactory, Free Text Index

    • Field Detail

      • NAMESPACE

        static final String NAMESPACE
        The namespace used for magic search predicates.

        See Also:
        SEARCH, RELEVANCE, RANK, #NUM_MATCHED_TOKENS, Constant Field Values

      • SEARCH

        static final org.openrdf.model.URI SEARCH
        The name of a magic predicate recognized in SPARQL queries when it occurs in statement patterns such as: 
         
 ( s?, bigdata:search, "scale-out RDF triplestore" )
        The value MUST be bound and MUST be a literal. The languageCode attribute is permitted. When specified, the languageCode attribute will be used to determine how the literal is tokenized - it does not filter for matches marked with that languageCode attribute. The datatype attribute is not allowed.

        The subject MUST NOT be bound.

        This expression will evaluate to a set of bindings for the subject position corresponding to the indexed literals matching any of the terms obtained when the literal was tokenized.

        Note: The context position should be unbound when using statement identifiers.

      • RELEVANCE

        static final org.openrdf.model.URI RELEVANCE
        Magic predicate used to query for free text search metadata, reporting the relevance of the search result to the search query. Use in conjunction with SEARCH as follows: 

         
 select ?s ?relevance
 where {
   ?s bds:search "scale-out RDF triplestore" .
   ?s bds:relevance ?relevance .
 }
        Relevance is the cosine of the angle between the query vector (search terms) and the document vector (terms in the indexed literals). The minimum relevance is ZERO (0.0). The maximum relevance is ONE (1.0).
        See Also:
        MIN_RELEVANCE, MAX_RELEVANCE

      • RANK

        static final org.openrdf.model.URI RANK
        Magic predicate used to query for free text search metadata, reporting the rank (origin ONE (1)) of the search result amoung the search results obtained for the search query. The rank is from ONE to N, where N is the number of search results from the full text index. MIN_RANK and MAX_RANK may be used to "slice" the full text index search results. Use this query hint conjunction with SEARCH as follows: 

         
 select ?s ?rank
 where {
   ?s bds:search "scale-out RDF triplestore" .
   ?s bds:rank ?rank .
 }
        See Also:
        MIN_RANK, MAX_RANK

      • MAX_RANK

        static final org.openrdf.model.URI MAX_RANK
        Magic predicate used to limit the maximum rank of the free text search results to the specified value (default . Use in conjunction with SEARCH as follows: 

         
 select ?s
 where {
   ?s bds:search "scale-out RDF triplestore" .
   ?s bds:maxRank "5"^^xsd:int .
 }
        You can use MIN_RANK and MAX_RANK together to page through the search results. This is often key to achieving low latency graph search. By limiting the number of results that are fed into the remained of the SPARQL query, you can ensure that the SPARQL query runs quickly. If you do not get enough results from the SPARQL query, you can feed the next "page" of free text results by changing the values for the MIN_RANK AND MAX_RANK query hints.

      • DEFAULT_MAX_RANK

        static final int DEFAULT_MAX_RANK
        The default for MAX_RANK.
        See Also:
        Constant Field Values

      • MIN_RANK

        static final org.openrdf.model.URI MIN_RANK
        Magic predicate used to limit the minimum rank of the free text search results to the specified value (default 1). Use in conjunction with SEARCH as follows: 

         
 select ?s
 where {
   ?s bds:search "scale-out RDF triplestore" .
   ?s bds:minRank "5"^^xsd:int .
 }
        The default is 1.

      • DEFAULT_MIN_RANK

        static final int DEFAULT_MIN_RANK
        The default for MIN_RANK is 1, full text search results will start with the #1 most relevant hit by default.
        See Also:
        Constant Field Values

      • MIN_RELEVANCE

        static final org.openrdf.model.URI MIN_RELEVANCE
        Magic predicate used to query for free text search metadata. Use in conjunction with SEARCH as follows: 

         
 select ?s
 where {
   ?s bds:search "scale-out RDF triplestore" .
   ?s bds:minRelevance "0.5"^^xsd:double .
 }
        The relevance scores are in [0.0:1.0], where 0.0 is the minimum possible relevance and 1.0 is the maximum possible relevance. You should NOT specify a minimum relevance of ZERO (0.0) as this can drag in way too many unrelated results. The default is 0.0.

      • DEFAULT_MIN_RELEVANCE

        static final double DEFAULT_MIN_RELEVANCE
        See Also:
        Constant Field Values

      • MAX_RELEVANCE

        static final org.openrdf.model.URI MAX_RELEVANCE
        Magic predicate used to query for free text search metadata. Use in conjunction with SEARCH as follows: 

         
 select ?s
 where {
   ?s bds:search "scale-out RDF triplestore" .
   ?s bds:maxRelevance "0.9"^^xsd:double .
 }
        The relevance scores are in [0.0:1.0], where 0.0 is the minimum possible relevance and 1.0 is the maximum possible relevance. You should NOT specify a minimum relevance of ZERO (0.0) as this can drag in way too many unrelated results. The default maximum relevance is 1.0.

      • DEFAULT_MAX_RELEVANCE

        static final double DEFAULT_MAX_RELEVANCE
        The default value for MAX_RELEVANCE unless overridden.
        See Also:
        Constant Field Values

      • MATCH_ALL_TERMS

        static final org.openrdf.model.URI MATCH_ALL_TERMS
        Magic predicate used to query for free text search metadata indicates that all terms in the query must be found within a given literal in order for that literal to "match" the query (default false). Use in conjunction with SEARCH as follows: 

         
 select ?s
 where {
   ?s bds:search "scale-out RDF triplestore" .
   ?s bds:matchAllTerms "true" .
 }

      • DEFAULT_MATCH_ALL_TERMS

        static final boolean DEFAULT_MATCH_ALL_TERMS
        See Also:
        Constant Field Values

      • MATCH_EXACT

        static final org.openrdf.model.URI MATCH_EXACT
        Magic predicate used to query for free text search metadata indicates that only exact string matches will be reported (the literal must contain the search string). Use in conjunction with SEARCH as follows: 

         
 select ?s
 where {
   ?s bds:search "scale-out RDF triplestore" .
   ?s bds:matchExact "true" .
 }

        This operation will be rather expensive as it will require materializing all the hits to check their values.

      • DEFAULT_MATCH_EXACT

        static final boolean DEFAULT_MATCH_EXACT
        See Also:
        Constant Field Values

      • MATCH_REGEX

        static final org.openrdf.model.URI MATCH_REGEX
        Magic predicate used to query for free text search metadata indicates that only search results that also pass the specified REGEX filter will be reported. Use in conjunction with SEARCH as follows: 

         
 select ?s
 where {
   ?s bds:search "scale-out RDF triplestore" .
   ?s bds:matchRegex "regex to apply to ?s bindings" .
 }

        This operation will be rather expensive as it will require materializing all the hits to check their values.

      • DEFAULT_MATCH_REGEX

        static final String DEFAULT_MATCH_REGEX

      • PREFIX_MATCH

        @Deprecated
static final org.openrdf.model.URI PREFIX_MATCH
        Deprecated. Prefix matching is now invoked using a wildcard.
        Prefix matching is now indicated using a wildcard 
         PREFIX bds: 
 
 SELECT ?subj ?label 
 WHERE {
       ?label bds:search "mi*" .
       ?label bds:relevance ?cosine .
       ?subj ?p ?label .
 }
        The following approach is no longer supported. Magic predicate used to query for free text search metadata to turn on prefix matching. Prefix matching will match all full text index tokens that begin with the specified token(s) (default false). Use in conjunction with SEARCH as follows: 

         
 select ?s
 where {
   ?s bds:search "scale-out RDF triplestore" .
   ?s bds:prefixMatch "true" .
 }

        This will turn on prefix matching.

        See Also:
        prefixMatch does not work in full text search

      • DEFAULT_PREFIX_MATCH

        static final boolean DEFAULT_PREFIX_MATCH
        Deprecated. This option is now invoked using a wildcard.
        See Also:
        Constant Field Values

      • SUBJECT_SEARCH

        @Deprecated
static final org.openrdf.model.URI SUBJECT_SEARCH
        Deprecated. Feature was never completed due to scalability issues. See BZLG-1548, BLZG-563.
        Magic predicate used to query for free text search metadata. Use in conjunction with SEARCH as follows: 

         
 select ?s
 where {
   ?s bds:search "scale-out RDF triplestore" .
   ?s bds:subjectSearch "true" .
 }

        The subject-centric search index must be enabled via AbstractTripleStore.Options.SUBJECT_CENTRIC_TEXT_INDEX.

      • DEFAULT_SUBJECT_SEARCH

        @Deprecated
static final boolean DEFAULT_SUBJECT_SEARCH
        Deprecated. 
        See Also:
        Constant Field Values

      • SEARCH_IN_SEARCH

        static final org.openrdf.model.URI SEARCH_IN_SEARCH
        Magic predicate used for the "search in search" service. Also serves as the identifier for the service itself.

      • SEARCH_TIMEOUT

        static final org.openrdf.model.URI SEARCH_TIMEOUT
        Magic predicate used to query for free text search metadata to set a deadline in milliseconds on the full text index search ( 9223372036854775807L). Use in conjunction with SEARCH as follows: 

         
 select ?s
 where {
   ?s bds:search "scale-out RDF triplestore" .
   ?s bds:searchTimeout "5000" .
 }

        Timeout specified in milliseconds.

      • DEFAULT_TIMEOUT

        static final long DEFAULT_TIMEOUT
        The default timeout for a free text search (milliseconds).
        See Also:
        Constant Field Values

      • RANGE_COUNT

        static final org.openrdf.model.URI RANGE_COUNT
        Magic predicate to specify that we want a range count done on the search. Bind the range count to the variable in the object position. Will attempt to do a fast range count on the index rather than materializing the hits into an array. This is only possible if matchExact == false and matchRegex == null.
